title: CALENDAR: FLOWERS AND CRAFTS

body: In 1928, when the Pascack Theater in Westwood opened, it was a 1,200-seat deluxe movie house with facilities for stage productions and a specially built Wurlitzer pipe organ for accompanying silent films. Among other things, the organ's sound effects included hoof beats, castanets, bells and harps. The theater was recently restored, and on Friday
title: New Jersey Guide; CHAPLIN IN WESTWOOD

body: New York City took a significant step yesterday toward building a plant in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard that would burn as much as 15 percent of the city's daily collection of garbage and convert it into steam. An Illinois energy and engineering company was chosen over three other companies to construct and operate the Brooklyn plant, which the
title: A STEAM PLANT BURNING REFUSE DUE IN BROOKLYN

Happily, however, there is a place where children and young people are cast, and where four productions and more than 100 performances are offered each
title: Going Out Guide

body: A 57-year-old woman confined to a wheelchair committed suicide yesterday morning by throwing herself out of a 12th-floor window at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights, according to the police. The woman went to the window in her wheelchair, then lifted herself out of it and pushed herself through the window. She fell through a grating into the
title: Invalid Woman, 57, A Suicide in Brooklyn

body: Lorry Russell sharing part of her day yesterday with the pigeons in Brooklyn Heights. Her family lives in Washington, and she was unable to join them for the holiday.
title: The New York Times/John Sotomayor THANKSGIVING WITH FRIENDS

body: Two jazz artists of legendary stature - the vocalist Ella Fitzgerald and the pianist Oscar Peterson - will share the stage of Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M., along with a guest artist, the guitarist Joe Pass. Miss Fitzgerald will be backed by the Jimmy Rowles Trio and Mr. Peterson will appear with John Heard on bass. Tickets, $10
title: WEEKENDER GUIDE; Friday; FISHER HALL JAZZ GREATS

body: In his 30th-floor law office in lower Manhattan yesterday, Kim Sperduto recalled easily the beginning of his work on the case that he won Tuesday in Federal Court in Brooklyn. title: FOR A YOUNG LAWYER, THE GENESIS OF A SIGNAL VICTORY

body: Red Hook, Brooklyn's legendary waterfront, survived generations of poor immigrants, brawling workers and union corruption, only to be nearly destroyed by government decisions. It is now beginning a renaissance, this time aided by government. ''Red Hook is one of the best examples I know of a neighborhood that has seen both the positive and the
title: RED HOOK SURVIVES HARD TIMES INTO NEW ERA

Was the name the product of some marketing strategy, like designer jeans or the car named Le

Darrow has been appointed general counsel of The New York Times Company, with responsibility for all of the company's legal affairs, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday. body: Teen-agers will tell you the rules of traveling in the city. ''The key is to look like you don't have any money,'' said Theresa O'Neill, 17, of Staten Island. title: LANDSCAPE AS DESIGN: 2 SHOWS FOCUS ON OLMSTED

Yet there it is, not quite the real thing, but a vision of things to come, seen in these attractive rooms of the landmark Villard

body: Landlords of buildings in one of the most expensive sections of Manhattan - the area between Fifth and Lexington Avenues from 59th to 79th Street - may soon qualify for substantial income-tax writeoffs. The first steps toward that status have been taken in Washington and at City Hall. Congress has passed a new rule on deductions for rehabilitation
title: HISTORIC STATUS MAY AID LANDLORDS ON EAST SIDE

body: Three years ago, Joseph Leo and his family moved from their Greenwich Village apartment to a century-old Queen Anne house on a quarter-acre lot in the St. George section of Staten Island. title: OUTER BOROUGHS ATTRACT COUPLES SEEKING A HOME

Altchek, a printing company executive and founder and president of the Sephardic Jewish Center in Forest Hills, Queens, died Saturday af an illness of six months at Mount Sinai Hospital. title: Solomon D. Altchek, Founder Of a Sephardic Jewish Center

title: DISPARATE INTERESTS JOINED IN FIGHTING NEW DISTRICTS

title: RACHEL CARSON AND THE WAR ON THE FRUIT FLY

body: You've planned a picnic for this Labor Day weekend, and along with the Brie, the French loaves, the chicken in pesto and the pasta salads and the California white in the cooler, you plan perhaps to bring a wedge of sweet and sticky gateau, some nice ripe fruit, maybe some sweetish soft drinks. Then you think about the bees. It is still heavy
title: HOW NOT TO GET STUNG

body: HUMOROUS BACH Bach in a joking vein will wind up a festival devoted to the composer that has been under way Tuesday evenings in Brooklyn Heights. title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: THE 1980's were to be the disastrous decade in which enrollments in higher education plummeted, pushing more and more colleges and universities to the brink of disaster. There would be fewer high school graduates, and admissions officers would struggle to fill freshman classes. The number of high school graduates has, as predicted, begun declining
title: DESPITE FORECASTS, COLLEGE ENROLLMENTS GROW

body: Entering the last days of the 1981 primary campaign, candidates both familiar and not so familiar fanned out across New York City over the weekend to rouse a mostly languorous voting public. The summer campaign had not been as galvanizing as last year's races, which came against the backdrop of a Presidential election year. And as potential voters
title: AS PRIMARY CAMPAIGN WINDS DOWN, CANDIDATES GO WHERE THE VOTERS ARE

body: After shopping in vain for a Manhattan apartment she could afford, Margaret Erlanger, a marketing assistant at American Express, recently purchased a 3 1/2-room co-op in a high rise in Forest Hills, Queens, for $26,000. Although she is not happy in Queens and plans to use the apartment ''as leverage to get back to the city'' she is pleased with the
title: DISCOVERING CO-OPS THAT ARE AFFORDABLE

title: Topics; MOVING AROUND THE CITY; Camouflage Chic

body: Now, five years later, he has seven hives in the backyard of his Boerum Hill brownstone. He never buys sugar. And he has more than a hundred pounds of honey left over each year to sell locally. A Phi Beta Kappa and an English teacher by profession, Mr. Auditore was curious about the bee dance, the circular walks and waggles by which worker bees
title: THE BEEKEEPER WHO GREW IN BROOKLYN; TONY AUDITORE lives in downtown Brooklyn with three cats, an Afghan hound and several hundred thousand honeybees. "I never expected to get any honey in the city," he said recently, stirring a spoonful of the heavy liquid into his jasmine tea. "I started bee keeping for the pure pleasure of learning about bees."

body: The summer weekend in the country is a splendid thing: fresh air and vegetables, beaches and concerts, barbecues and bare feet. There is only one tiny flaw, and its name is Sunday night, otherwise known as coming back to the city. If it wasn't bad enough to return to hot sidewalks and hotter subways, there is the process of leaving itself, which
title: ON WEEKENDS, ALAS, ALL ROADS LEAD HOME

body: Junior's Restaurant, a landmark in downtown Brooklyn that for 30 years had been a magnet for hurrying office workers, relaxing families and deal-making politicians, was a scarred ruin yesterday as a result of a three-alarm fire. The blaze was discovered around the 1:30 A.M. closing time in the two-story structure at DeKalb Avenue and the Flatbush
title: BROOKLYN BLAZE CLOSES LANDMARK RESTAURANT

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

title: Miss Wittenstein Bride of Student

body: The problems of building cities are enormous, and the way they are built has profound and inescapable consequences. Buildings form the framework for all the city's activities; their size, quality and distribution create its appeal and amenity, and
title: Architecture View; A PLAN TO PRESERVE THE UPPER EAST SIDE

body: Jacques de Roquancourt arrived in New York from Paris two years ago determined to make his way as a developer. Almost the first thing he did was to start walking. title: About Real Estate; A BROOKLYN HEIGHTS SITE, A DEVELOPER FROM PARIS

body: It's a problem and not a problem. Betsy Gotbaum is a 42-year-old woman who looks like a fresh-faced college senior. It's not a problem when she wants to wangle something for her favorite organization in the city, the state and maybe the world -the New York
title: A POLICE VOICE FROM AN UNLIKELY SOURCE

body: As the temperature rose relentlessly to 95 degrees yesterday and the fumes poured from the cars coming off the nearby West Side Highway, Valentino Paolilla stood shoulder-deep in a hole on 42d Street drilling concrete. Mr. Paolilla is one of the construction workers who are resurfacing the road under what used to be the West Side Highway. He spent
title: LOOKING WARMLY AT A HOT 95o DAY

body: The heaviest Fourth-of-July rainfall on record dampened spirits but not celebrations, as the city engaged in its annual round of parades, volleys of fireworks, fairs and artillery salutes. From neighborhood parades with parochial school bands and ancient fire trucks to the setting off of fireworks displays, participants defied the downpour - which
title: RAIN CURTAILS FOURTH OF JULY CROWDS

body: To the Editor: I was feeling quite sorry for the people described by Lee Daniels in ''City Apartment Hunt: Tale of Sore Feet and Sad Luck'' (news story June 20): all those people competing for the opportunity to pay $1,000 monthly rents in a few square blocks of Manhattan. It was even a chore to locate an apartment in desirable areas of Brooklyn
title: THE BRONX BECKONS APARTMENT HUNTERS

body: FOURTH of July celebrations will be staged all over the metropolitan region this weekend. The air over Coney Island will be filled this weekend with
title: FROM FIREWORKS TO PARADES: A JULY FOURTH GUIDE

body: In the beginning there was a law that allowed a couple of farmers to trade fields Maybe they wanted a shorter walk to their respective barns. By trading, instead of buying and selling the two fields, they avoided paying capital gains taxes. That was decades ago. Today the same law is the basis for one of the most active tools used in real-estate
title: PROPERTY SWAPPED TO SAVE TAXES

body: William L. Hamm Sr., an attorney who specialized in maritime law and represented foreign countries before the Federal Maritime Commission, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital after a long illness. He lived in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn and was 67 years old. Mr. Hamm was the retired chairman of the Associated
title: William L. Hamm Sr., 67, Lawyer Who Specialized in Maritime Law

title: THE EVENING HOURS

body: New York City's plan to build a steam plant that would burn 3,000 tons of garbage a day in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard has prompted borough residents to begin voicing fear, suspicion and opposition. The plant would be the first of up to a dozen such facilities the Koch administration says are needed to avoid inundating the city in garbage within
title: CITY PLAN FOR GARBAGE-FUELED PLANT DRAWS ANGER OF BROOKLYN RESIDENTS

body: When he was a little boy, Jon Lehman played the clarinet briefly in school and sometimes fantasized about being a great violinist. As he grew up, married, had a daughter and went into his family's printing business, the clarinet and the fantasy receded into his childhood memories. When the Lehmans enrolled their daughter in a music program at the
title: MUSICIANS FIND COMMON THEME AT HENRY ST. SETTLEMENT

body: Preserving the architectural quality of a neighborhood and protecting its commercial vitality are often opposite ends. In designating a 1,044-building chunk of Manhattan's Upper East Side as a historic district last week, New York's Landmarks Preservation Commission took pains to reach one goal without obstructing the other. Although it considered
title: The Region In Summary; A PLAN TO PRESERVE WITHOUT FREEZING

body: The decision on Tuesday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission to give blanket landmark protection to a 1,044-building chunk of the Upper East Side is the strongest pro-preservation stance the city has taken since it went to the United States Supreme Court to argue on behalf of the saving of the Grand Central Terminal. It will not necessarily end
title: PRESERVATION VICTORY; News Analysis

body: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted yesterday to create a historic district on a gilded stretch of Manhattan's East Side that abuts Central Park and forms an architectural evocation of old New York. The designation, which follows two years of debate and study, in effect confers landmark status on 1,044 buildings on nearly every block
title: PANEL CREATES A HISTORIC DISTRICT IN MANHATTAN'S EAST 60'S AND 70'S

body: A walking tour of Brooklyn Heights and a lecture on the home care of antiques are part of the third Brooklyn Heights Antiques Show, which runs this weekend at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, on Orange Street, between Hicks and Henry Streets. Thirty dealers from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will exhibit American and English antiques
title: Brooklyn Heights Antique Show Is On

Moderating this weekend's two-day conference on collecting art for pleasure rather than investment will be Channel 13's Robert MacNeil. title: CALENDAR: COLLECTING ART AND CITY SHRUBS

The garden will hold its largest plant sale of the year tomorrow through Sunday on the mall in front of the Museum Building. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: FLOWERS AND POTTERY

body: A NEW CROP House plants, annuals, perennials, trees, shrubs, herbs, cacti and succulents are available today and tomorrow at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's annual spring plant sale, which is featuring Primula obconmica, an indoor everblooming primrose, and drought-tolerant plants such as rosemary, parsley, sedums, geraniums, marigolds and zinnias.
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: ANTIQUE clothing shops have a special fascination. Sometimes one picks up bargains, but their larger attraction is nostalgia: finding fabrics and workmanship that no longer exist or recapturing a period in the muslin-and-lace lingerie of the Victorians, the beaded chiffons of the 20's, the paper doll silhouette of the 50's and even the go-go boots
title: DISCOVERIES

body: ON wheels, on foot and on camel, New Yorkers and their neighbors will be celebrating the arrival of May this weekend in the only reasonable way -by getting out of doors. Probably the most noticeable among them will be the participants in the annual Five Boro Bike Tour - some 17,000 are expected to turn out, according to the sponsors of the event,
title: CITY AND SUBURB GOING ALL OUT FOR MAY

body: ''I believe in the free market,'' Felix Rohatyn said one morning, sitting in his apartment 12 floors above Park Avenue. ''But I do not believe in laissez-faire.'' It was a lovely, assuring day. title: ROHATYN, 'GOING NATIONAL,' DOUBTS FREE-MARKET FUTURE

title: FINE LIVING, WHERE DID YOU GO?

body: A mother and child on the promenade quietly enjoying yesterday's 70-degree temperature. Today may prove to be a different story - the metropolitan forecast calls for a chance of thunderstorms.
title: NAP IN THE BROOKLYN HEIGHTS SUN

body: ''They never laid a glove on us,'' was William G. Hundley's chipper response when Richard A. Williams, the key witness in the mail fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, finished his direct testimony Friday afternoon. The remark summed up the upbeat and optimistic attitude - at least publicly - of Mr. Margiotta, the Republican Party
title: No Headline

body: EVERYONE will be thinking pink at the wedding April 11 of Evangeline Gouletas and Governor Carey. Miss Gouletas will be wearing a lowwaisted pink satin gown with full skirt, chiffon bodice and sleeves, and it's being feverishly stitched together this very minute by the New York couturier Stavropoulos. Stavropoulos is also creating the gowns for the
title: THE EVENING HOURS

body: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Middle Eastern Unity March 25 - Jihan el Sadat, Egypt's First Lady, will receive the World Rehabilitation Funds first Achievement Award for her service in establishing the Rehabilitation
title: FUTURE EVENTS

body: The engagement of Susan Elizabeth Cogger to Norman Edward Mitchell 3d, son of Colonel Mitchell 2d, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Mitchell of Pawling, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Everett Banks of Clearwater, Fla. An April 25 wedding is planned in the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights. Miss Cogger, daughter also
title: Norman Mitchell 3d to Marry Susan Cogger

body: After more than a decade of delays, New York City was ready to begin a billion-dollar effort to complete its basic sewage treatment system. But city officials now say President Reagan's proposed budget cuts once again threaten the entire program. The city had planned to ask the Federal Government for $560 million in the next fiscal year to complete
title: REAGAN CUTS VIEWED AS THREAT TO CITY SEWAGE TREATMENT PROJECT

body: Following are the scores, released last week by the Board of Education, on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1980. The figures supplement a report made available in September showing that overall reading achievement in the school system increased in 1980 from the year before. ''We have
title: TESTS SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN READING IN CITY SCHOOLS

body: Haagen-Dazs ice cream comes in pint and half-pint containers with lids that feature a map of Scandinavia, but it's made by a Polish immigrant, all in New Jersey. The label of another brand, Alpen Zauber, touts a ''Swiss commitment to excellence.'' But Alpen Zauber is made entirely in Brooklyn. And Frusen Gladje? The company is incorporated in
title: Rolls-Royces of Ice Cream

body: ''There are a lot more sacrifices than first meet the eye,'' said Theodore Bushlow of his move into a seven-family town-house cooperative in Brooklyn Heights. But despite having to live ''in a world of compromise,'' Mr. Bushlow, a lawyer, is happy that he selected a small building. Mr. Bushwick and other owners of apartments in small buildings said
title: CONFLICTS AND JOYS:LIFE IN A SMALL CO-OP

body: In recognition of the approach of spring, a reading of poetry and prose about baseball will take place tonight at 8 in St. Ann's School in Brooklyn. The evening's lineup includes Roger Kahn, author of ''The Boys of Summer'' and ''A Season in the Sun''; Joel Oppenheimer, poet, playwright and Dodger fan,and Joe Flaherty, sports columnist. Admission,
title: Brooklyn Ode to Baseball

body: It is hard not to think that the Westway could have been built by now, so prolonged has been the debate over this immense highway, landfill and park project for Manhattan's West Side. It was first proposed in the early 1970's, and the controversy that surrounds it seems to have grown more intense with each passing year. The debate has taken on
title: DEBATE ON WESTWAY CONCERNS CONCEPTS OF CITY'S FUTURE; An Appraisal

body: FROM 1853 to 1929, nearly 100,000 impoverished orphans who had no place to live but the streets of New York were transported to new families and new lives by the Children's Aid Society. These children were taken to homes waiting to welcome them across the country on a caravan of railroad cars known as orphan trains. This is the story that Dorothea
title: BROADWAY; Leach to direct musical on orphans going west by rail.

body: AN ingredient essential to the New York nosh is the New York waiter. So when Lou Singer brought the six women from his Nosher's Tour of New York into Gertel's Kosher Bakery at 53 Hester Street the other day, there was little surprise when the waiter, with blond walrus mustache and several tattoos, asked somewhat brusquely, ''You gonna sit like that
title: A SNACKING TOUR OF THE NEIGHBORHOODS

body: GO west, young man, I thought. The time arrived when I knew I had to leave the comfortable womb I've called Long Island, and start a new chapter of my life. The decision did not come lightly. Friends and family admonished about the disadvantages of leaving the Island, trying to dissuade me from making my inevitable exodus. But, after long
title: LEAVING IT BUT STILL LOVING IT

body: Henrik Antell, a former purchasing agent of The New York Times, died Friday at the Veterans Medical Center in Canandaigua, N.Y. He was 85 years old and a resident of Brooklyn Heights. He was born in Brooklyn and received his B.A. from Cornell University. He joined the Army in World War I, and in World War II was a major, and later a colonel, in the
title: Henrik Antell, Purchasing Agent At The Times for 17 Years, Dies

body: FOR those who live in the city but enjoy a campfire in the chill of winter, there are a number of places in the metropolitan area that sell everything from firewood to Irish peat to warm the hearth. As prices vary, care and patience will help in finding the bargains. For practical purposes, firewood is generally sold in bags or bundles of 10 to 12
title: AT YOUR SERVICE: WOOD FOR THE FIREPLACE

body: BEFORE THE THEATER Finding a restaurant to dine in, or to have a drink in, before or after the theater ought to be easy; it is not. The best-known restaurants get crowded; some of the lesser-known restaurants you would not want to go to, anyway. For the most part, the best known, and therefore most crowded, restaurants are between Broadway and
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: ''My Name Is'' was the name of the world premiere of a new work by Steve Reich, performed with his repertory players in the first of the three concerts of this year's Composers' Showcase at the Whitney Museum of American Art Tuesday night; it is a ''work in progress'' related to a similar piece dating from 1967. The performers in Mr. Reich's
title: CONCERTS: 3 EVENINGS IN THE 'COMPOSERS' SHOWCASE' AT THE WHITNEY MUSEUM
